name: Gar Ainion
text:
The GAR AINION was a place, or a high square, in the city of Gondolin
where weddings were held, and it was dedicated to the Valar.


Etymology

The name meant “Place of the Gods” in Sindarin.

name: Morgai
text:
MORGAI also known as the BLACK FENCE was a mountainous ridge in the
Ephel Dúath (Mountains of Shadow) which formed a defensive wall.

Between it lay a road which ran between Durthang and the Morgul Pass.

name: Crickhollow
text:
CRICKHOLLOW was a village in Buckland located a few
miles north of Bucklebury.


History

In TA 3018, Frodo Baggins bought a house in Crickhollow after leaving
Bag End, as he was about to exit the Shire.

name: Eithel Sirion
text:
EITHEL SIRION is a spring in Middle-earth, in Beleriand. It drained into
the River Sirion. Fingolfin built a great fortress in this location
called Barad Eithel and that was also called sometimes Eithel Sirion.
description: Beautiful spring of water of Sirion

name: Durin's Tower
text:
DURIN'S TOWER was a dwarvish tower that stood on the peak of
Zirakzigil above Moria, at which Gandalf defeated Durin's Bane.

It could only be reached by a long stairwell which began in the deep far
below the mines.
description: Carved out of the living rock of the mountain

name: Old Mill
text:
The OLD MILL was located
on The Water in Hobbiton. It was owned by Ted Sandyman, and during the
Scouring of the Shire was burnt down during the War of the Ring by
Ruffians. Afterwards, it was rebuilt as the New Mill.

name: Orrostar
text:
The ORROSTAR ('Eastlands') were a group of hills located in the
easternmost province of Númenor. The hills themselves were located on
the northern coast of the province and they were known as the Granary of
the realm.

name: Harlond
text:
HARLOND (Sindarin for “south haven”) is a Elf-haven and a harbour on the
northern shores of Harlindon in the far western parts of Middle-earth.

The southern harbour on the Gulf of Lhûn was Mithlond, the northern
being Forlond.

name: Bay of Eldanna
text:
The_' Bay of Eldanna_' was the westernmost and largest bay on the island
of Númenor.

It was located between the arms of Andustar and Hyarnustar, two of the
five extruding points of Númenor. Its chief port was the haven
Eldalondë.

name: Ondosto
text:
ONDOSTÓ was a city in southern Forostar in Númenor.


History

It was situated on an important road that ran from Rómenna all the way
to the city of Andúnië and may have been associated with the stone that
was quarried in the region.
description: City of Númenor in the region of Forostar

name: Eastern Seas
text:
The EASTERN SEAS were a body of water that separated Middle-earth from
the Land of the Sun before the changing of Arda.

The seas were greatly enlarged after the change, and served as the new
border between the Far East and the New Lands.

name: Staddle
text:
STADDLE was a village in Bree Land, located on the southeastern side of
Bree-hill.


History

STADDLE was probably founded when Bree-land was settled. By the middle
of the Third Age, it was settled by mixed groups of Hobbits and Men
fleeing Angmar.

name: Girdley Island
text:
GIRDLEY ISLAND was a small island
in the middle of the Brandywine river.

Girdley Island was approximately four miles long and about a half mile
wide and located seven or eight miles from the Brandywine Bridge,
according to _The Atlas of Middle-earth_.
position: Brandywine River; in the Shire's Eastfarthing

name: Folde
text:
The FOLDE was a historic region in the Eastfold of Rohan. It was mainly
tall grasslands, with a moderate climate.

The Folde was famous for having been the original homeland of Rohan's
royal establishment that was seated in the capital city of Aldburg.

name: Mountains of Mithrim
text:
The Mountains of Mithrim were mountains in Hithlum running northwest
from the Ered Engrin. This mountain chain formed the boundary between
Mithrim and Dor-lomin.

The caves of Androth were probably located on the eastern slopes of the
Mountains of Mithrim.

name: Forlond
text:
FORLOND was a harbour in the sorthern part of Forlindon on the coast of
Gulf of Lhûn in the northwest of Middle-earth.


History

Forlond was built by Elves after the drowning of Beleriand.


Etymology

_FORLOND_ is a Sindarin word that meant 'North-haven'.

name: The Citadel
text:
THE CITADEL of Gondor sits atop the seventh and highest level of Minas
Tirith, Gondor's capital. The Citadel houses the Throne of Gondor as
well as the Steward's Chair. The Citadel has access to the Fountain
Court. The Citadel also has access to the Tower of Ecthelion.

name: Obel Halad
text:
OBEL HALAD was the fortified place in Brethil in which stood the Hall of
the Halad (Hall of the Chieftains of Brethil).


History

It was to Obel Halad that Manthor, with Forhend and Húrin, came from
Haudh-en-Elleth to assist Húrin on his “errand” and bring him to
Chieftan Hardang.

name: Undeeps
text:
There are two UNDEEPS: the north and the south Undeeps. They were two
great westward lands of the Anduin, located between the Brown Lands and
the great Wold of Rohan, East of Fangorn forest. They were strategic
points when Eorl and his men came from the North to the Fields of
Celebrant.
position: Between The Wold and the Brown Lands
events: Counterattack upon the Wainriders, The Battle of the Field of Celebrant
description: Two large shallow bends in the Anduin

name: Tol Fuin
text:
_' Tol Fuin_' was one of the few areas of land that escaped the drowning
of Beleriand. It originally was the land of Taur-nu-Fuin. When the world
was changed, its highest parts survived as the island TOL FUIN (Isle of
Night), part of the Western Isles.

es:Tol Fuin pl:Tol Fuin ru:Тол Фуин

name: Nimbretril
text:
NIMBRETRIL was a forest of Birchwood in Arvernien at the Havens of
Sirion in the southwestern Beleriand.

Eärendil used the birchwood from these woods as timber in the
construction of Vingilot, the Foam-flower.

It was also mentioned in a song written by Bilbo called the Song of
Eärendil.

name: Nindamos
text:
NINDAMOS was considered the chief settlement of the fishermen of
Númenor, in the south of the island.


History

It was set amongst the marshes at the mouth of the River Siril.

Nindamos was the largest of several small villages scattered throughout
the Hyarnustar and Hyarrostar regions of Númenor.

name: Houses of the Dead
text:
The HOUSES OF THE DEAD were a crypt on the top level of Minas Tirith. It
was here that the Stewards of Gondor were buried.

When Denethor's madness set in in _The Return of the King_, he took
Faramir to the Houses, intending to burn both Faramir and himself alive
on a pyre, thinking him to be dead.
description: Ancient series of crypts and tombs for Gondor's nobility

name: Woods of Oromë
text:
The WOODS OF OROMË are a forested area in southeastern Valinor between
the Pastures of Yavanna and the Hyamentir.


History

It was used by Oromë probably for hunting purposes. It was observed by
both Ungoliant and Melkor as they scaled the high-points of the Pelóri
on their way to destroy the Two Trees.

name: Ethring
text:
ETHRING was a large town built on either side of the river Ringló at a
major crossing of that river, the only recorded town in the Ringló Vale.
A major road that led from Morthond Vale to Pelargir ran through it.

During the War of the Ring, Aragorn crossed the river Ringló at Ethring
with his Army of the Dead.

name: Oromet
text:
OROMET was a hill in the Andustar region of Númenor.

It was located very close to the shoreline in the utmost west of the
region near the haven of Andúnië.


History

Being high and as closest that a Man not on a ship could get to the
Undying Lands, Tar-Minastir, who longed for the lands west built a high
tower on the hill.

name: Tuckborough
text:
TUCKBOROUGH
is a location in the Westfarthing of The Shire. Being the main village
of Tookland, it is where most of the Took clan resided. It was located
at the western end of the Green Hill Country. The Stock Road ran
eastward from Tuckborough to Stock.

This region was the site of the Great Smials, the ancestral home of the
Thains.

name: Tumhalad
text:
TUMHALAD was a field in the western Beleriand between the rivers Narog
and Ginglith north of Nargothrond.


History

Tumhalad was where the disastrous Battle of Tumhalad took place in the
latter part of the First Age. It, like every other land in
Beleriand, fell under the Great Sea after the War of Wrath at the end of
the First Age.

name: Wall of the Sun
text:
The WALL OF THE SUN was a vast mountain range in the Land of the Sun in
the far eastern part of Arda during the time before the Change of the
World.

The Wall of the Sun's highest peak was Kalórmë, directly across Arda
from which lay the mountain of Taniquetil in Valinor. The land it was on
was across the Eastern Seas from Middle-Earth.

name: Harrowdale
text:
HARROWDALE was the name given to the deep north-south valley cut out of
the White Mountains by the Snowbourn river.

At its southern end, beneath the mountain known as the Starkhorn, stood
Dunharrow, a great refuge of the Rohirrim. At its northern end, where
the Snowbourn issued onto the plains of Rohan, stood that nation's
capital, Edoras.

name: Merethrond
text:
MERETHROND also known as the GREAT HALL OF FEASTS was a great hall in
Minas Tirith used by the nobility of Gondor for feasting. It is located
in the Citadel next to the Tower of Ecthelion.

Aragorn met Éomer at this place once the War of the Ring ended.


Etymology

_Merethrond_ is a Sindarin word that meant 'Fell-hall' or 'Hall of
Feasts'.
position: Citadel of Gondor in Minas Tirith
description: The feasting hall of the king in Gondor, filled with tables

name: Helm's Dike
text:
HELM'S DIKE was an ancient trench and rampart that lay in the area
surrounding Rohan's fortress of the Hornburg in the Region of Rohan.

It was about a quarter mile below the Burg of the fortress and stretched
about a mile or more across the Deeping Coomb. It was quite steep and
was about twenty feet high in some places and resembled a cliff.
description: Earthen wall and ditch

name: Morgul-road
text:
MORGUL-ROAD is the road that runs
through the Morgul Vale. Not to be confused with Cirith Ungol (also
known as the Nameless Pass, High Pass, or Pass of the Spider) which
Frodo and Sam went on to get to the Tower of Cirith Ungol in The Two
Towers and The Return of the King in the books, but in the movies it
only appears in The Return of the King.

name: Idril's Secret Way
text:
IDRIL'S SECRET WAY was an escape tunnel made by Idril Celebrindal under
the hidden city of Gondolin.


History

The Secret Way ran underneath the city possibly beginning from the house
of Tuor and Idril beyond its walls and proceeded northward of the Amon
Gwareth. Through the Secret Way, the last survivors of the doomed city
escaped its destruction.

name: Haudh-en-Elleth
text:
HAUDH-EN-ELLETH was the burial mound of Finduilas, located in Brethil
near the Crossings of Teiglin. The mound was kept free of orcs by Túrin
while he lived, and here he met (but did not recognize) his sister
Nienor for the first time. 

Years later, it was here that Manthor and his guardsmen came across
Húrin, during the time of Húrin's wanderings.

name: Tower of Turgon
text:
TOWER OF TURGON or the TOWER OF THE KING was a great tower in the city
of Gondolin built by King Turgon.

It stood in the King's Square in the very center of the city. During the
Fall of Gondolin, it was defended by the King's Household but they were
ultimately defeated and the tower thrown down. As it came crashing down,
it landed on the King killing him.

name: Calmindon
text:
CALMINDON was a massive lighthouse built upon Tol Uinen in the Bay of
Rómenna.


History

Calmindon was built by the future King Aldarion who was then head of the
Guild of Venturers in order to warn ships entering the bay. It was
destroyed along with Tol Uinen when Númenor was destroyed.


Etymology

Calmindon was Elvish for 'Shining-tower' or 'Light-tower'.

name: Chetwood
text:
Chetwood is a
small forest in the realm of Bree Land. The town of Archet is located at
its edge.

It is on the East-West Road northeast of Bree. Combe is situated on the
borders of Chetwood. The Great East Road runs through the southern edge
of Chetwood, while the Greenway runs through the western edge. On the
eastern side of Chetwood are the Midgewater Marshes.
description: Small forest near the Great East Road

name: Hidden Way
text:
The HIDDEN WAY was a tunnel in the Echoriath that led to the hidden city
of Gondolin.


History

The Hidden Way was once a river tunnel of the Dry River that had once
tributed the Sirion. It was fortified when Gondolin was built. Seven
Gates blocked the tunnel and it was heavy guarded. Tuor and Voronwë
passed through the Hidden Way when they both came to the city.

name: Hyarmentir
text:
HYARMENTIR was a mountain southeast of Valinor in Aman.


History

Hyarmentir was the highest mountain peak in southern Aman. Ungoliant's
Lair was located south of it. Before they destroyed the Two Trees,
Melkor and Ungoliant gazed upon the bliss of the Blessed Realm from one
of its highest peak.


Etymology

_Hyarmentir_ is a Quenyan word that meant 'South Watch'.
description: One of the tallest mountain peaks of Aman

name: Amon Darthir
text:
AMON DARTHIR was a mountain peak in the Ered Wethrin, south of
Dor-lómin.

The stream Nen Lalaith that flowed down into Dor-lómin near Húrin's
house was fed from a spring that came down from this mountain. Beneath
Amon Darthir's peak were a series of secret, difficult and narrow passes
that were the only ways through the Ered Wethrin when coming from that
direction.

name: Westfold
text:
The WESTFOLD was a region of Rohan that was east to the Gap of Rohan and
contained Helm's Deep. It bordered with the Eastfold via the Snowbourn
River.


History

Theoden rode with Gandalf to Helm's Deep to relieve Erkenbrand's
battered army.

During the War of the Ring the Westfold was attacked by Isengard and the
men of Dunland, and several villages were burned down.
position: Western Rohan, skirting the White Mountains
description: Slopes and fields
events: First Battle of the Fords of Isen, Second Battle of the Fords of Isen, Battle of the Hornburg

name: Bay of Andúnië
text:
The BAY OF ANDÚNIË was the northernmost of the three bays that ran along
the western coasts of the Andustar in Númenor. The greatest of the
three, its shores were no more than a narrow shelf of land from which
steep cliffs rose up. Beneath these cliffs at its eastern end was the
famous haven of Andúnië. There may have also been a second haven on this
bay, named Almaida.

name: Waymeet
text:
WAYMEET also known as WAYMOOT was a town in the Westfarthing of The
Shire.

It was located on the Great East Road about six or seven miles north of
Whitwell and about fifteen miles southwest of Hobbiton.

During the War of the Ring, the Ruffians working for Sharkey had sheds
there that they used as their barracks and it was from here that they
left for the Battle of Bywater.

name: Tol Galen
text:
TOL GALEN was a green isle that lay between the two arms of the River
Adurant in the south of Ossiriand, and was the center of a land known as
Dor Firn-i-Guinar.


History

Tol Galen was the place that Beren and Lúthien lived out the rest of
their mortal lives after being released from the Halls of Mandos.


Etymology

_TOL GALEN_ was a Sindarin word that meant 'Green Island'.

name: Eastern Shore
text:
The EASTERN SHORE was a location found between the Emyn Muil and the
River Anduin.


Inhabitants

During the Third Age, around the time of the War of the Ring, Orcs dwelt
on the Eastern Shore, coming out of Mordor to waylay travellers on the
river. They often took cover in the fog which hung there. The Fellowship
was attacked by Orcs of Mordor coming from this shore before it was
broken.

name: Woodhall
text:
WOODHALL was small Shire village near a hidden Elvish waystation in the
Eastfarthing of the Shire.


History

After meeting Frodo Baggins, Sam Gamgee, and Peregrin Took as they
crossed the Shire pursued by Black Riders, the High Elves led by Gildor
Inglorion hosted the Hobbits in a wide hall-like space in the woods,
roofed by the boughs of trees, by a clearing in the woods above
Woodhall.

name: Mount Rerir
text:
MOUNT RERIR was a mountain in Thargelion (a region of Beleriand) to the
north of Lake Helevorn and one of the sources of the Gelion.

The land around the mountain belonged to Caranthir, who built a fortress
on its western slopes. The fortress was destroyed during Dagor
Bragollach. Elven forces probably withdrew from the area after the
battle, and most definitely after Nirnaeth Arnoediad.

name: Bridge Inn
text:
The BRIDGE INN was an inn in Buckland.

The inn was located at the west-end of the Brandywine River on the Great
East Road.


History

During the War of the Ring when Lotho ruled the Shire, the inn was torn
down in favor of a gloomy-like guardhouse for the Chief's Men and their
Hobbit servants. It is unknown if it was rebuilt after the
cleansing of the Shire after end of the War of the Ring.

name: Andram
text:
ANDRAM was the long wall of hills that ran across Beleriand west to east
for nearly three-hundred miles, according to _The Atlas of
Middle-earth_, from Nargothrond to the Gates of Sirion and ending to
Ramdal.

Its easternmost hill was Amon Ereb, which usually was not considered a
part of Andram.


Etymology

_ANDRAM_ was a Sindarin word meaning 'long wall'. AND means long, and
RAM means wall.
position: Stretching across south Beleriand from Taur-en-Faroth to Ramdal
description: A long wall of hills

name: Far Downs
text:
The Far Downs, marked the
western boundary of the Shire until its expansion in FO 32.


History

The Far Downs was forty leagues from the Brandywine Bridge and over
forty miles from the Tower Hills. The town of Greenholm was built upon
it, and the Great East Road that led to the Tower Hills ran across it.
Fastred, the first Warden of Westmarch, was born on these hills in the
town of Greenholm.

name: Emerië
text:
EMERIË was a region in the middle of Númenor.

Emerië was a land of green valleys, where sheep were kept. The people of
Emerië were mainly of Bëorian origins, and they spoke an accented
Adûnaic with many Bëorian words and some other oddities.

Erendis, wife of Tar-Aldarion, came from Emerië, and after their strife
she returned here where she stayed until her death.

de:Emerië pl:Emerië ru:Эмериэ

name: Deeping Coomb
text:
Deeping Coomb is the deep, well-defended valley in the northern White
Mountains that held Helm's Deep and the castle of the Hornburg. The site
of an important battle, the Battle of the Hornburg, during the War of
the Ring. The word coomb is a rare Brythonic survival word (as in the
Welsh _cwm_); meaning a small deep dry valley, easily defended. It gives
its name to many places in the British Isles.

name: Ephel Brandir
text:
EPHEL BRANDIR (also called _the Ephel_) was a settlement that consisted
of the dwellings of the Men of Brethil in the Beleriand in Middle-earth.
It lay upon the hill of Amon Obel in the forest of Brethil and is where
Túrin was taken when he fell ill. It was ruled by Brandir son of Handir,
the sixth Chieftain of the Haladin.


Etymology

Ephel Brandir is Sindarin for _the encircling fence of Brandir._

name: Drúwaith Iaur
text:
DRÚWAITH IAUR also known as OLD PÚKEL LAND was a
land west of Gondor between the river Isen and the White Mountains.


History

Drúwaith Iaur was supposedly one of the homes to the remnants of the
Drúedain or Woses and perhaps other men who had once lived in the White
Mountains (Ered Nimrais), but Drúwaith Iaur population was never fully
established.


Etymology

Drúwaith Iaur was Sindarin for 'Old wild-folk'.

name: Tavrobel
text:
TAVROBEL was a town in the northwestern part of the island of Tol
Eressëa.


History

Tavrobel was established some time after the island was permanently
anchored in the Bay of Eldamar by the Vala Ulmo, at an unknown date
during the Years of the Trees. The elder elf Gilfanon was known to be
from here.

Eriol sojourned here during his visit to the island. 


Notable features

-   Bridge of Tavrobel
-   Tower of Tavrobel

name: Amon Dîn
text:
AMON DÎN or DÎN was the first and possibly the oldest of the seven
Warning beacons of Gondor and is located between the Drúadan Forest and
the Grey Wood.


History

It was originally used as a fortified position of the city of Minas
Tirith keeping watch over north Ithilien and Dagorlad. During the Siege
of Gondor, Amon Dîn was the second beacon to be lit.


Etymology

_Amon Dîn_ was Sindarin for 'Silent-moun', ''amon ''
position: Between Drúadan Forest and Grey Wood
description: One of the Warning beacons of Gondor

name: Mounds of the Kings of Rohan
text:
The MOUNDS OF THE KINGS OF ROHAN was where the Kings of Rohan were
buried.


History

The Mounds were located in Edoras somewhere probably near the Meduseld.
The Mounds consisted of two lines. The first line was where the first
nine kings were buried with Helm in the ninth and final one of that
line. After the death of Fréaláf Hildeson, a new line of Mounds was
begun were which all the kings afterwards were laid to rest.

name: Tol Morwen
text:
TOL MORWEN was the island located off the northwestern coasts of
Middle-earth, after the drowning of Beleriand at the end of the First
Age. 


History

One of the few locations in Beleriand which was not drowned, it was the
site of the Stone of the Hapless and the grave of Morwen Eledhwen, hence
its name. Mariners of Númenor and later Arnor visited it on their
voyages to pay respect to the hero Túrin Turambar buried there.

name: Pincup
text:
PINCUP was a village located in Green-hill country in the Southfarthing
of the Shire.

According to _The Atlas of Middle-earth_, it was a few miles south of
the Three Farthing Stone to the north of Green-hill and approximately
eighteen miles east of Tuckborough in the Westfarthing. It lay on the
southern slopes of the Green-hill and only one road led to it; the road
up from Longbottom in the far south of the Southfarthing.

name: Arvernien
text:
ARVERNIEN was a region in the southern Beleriand west of the Mouths of
Sirion.


History

The first rulers of the region of Arvernien, were Tuor and Idril who
were refugees from Gondolin. Later their son Eärendil Half-Elven,
married the Half-Elven Elwing, Dior's daughter and survivor of the Sack
of Doriath. Elros and Elrond, the sons of Eärendil and Elwing, were born
in Arvernien.


Etymology

_ARVERNIEN_ was a Sindarin word.
position: In Beleriand, south of Narog and west of Sirion
description: Coastal region of Balar

name: Pass of Aglon
text:
The PASS OF AGLON was connected to Lothlann and Himlad in the East
Beleriand during the First Age.


History

In the years after the Return of the Ñoldor to Middle-earth, it was one
of the dwelling places of Celegorm and Curufin up to FA 455 when it was
overrun by the forces of Morgoth during the Dagor Bragollach. The area
was destroyed along with the rest of the Beleriand at the end of the
First Age following the War of Wrath.
description: A cold, windy, narrow pass, steep-sided on the west

name: Sea of Ringol
text:
The SEA OF RINGOL was a great inland sea.

It is believed that the Sea of Ringol was formed from the meltwaters
that came after the destruction of Ormal.

Not much of known of this Southern Sea. In many books it is not shown,
and others just briefly show it. It is possible that it was one of the
many landforms (like its relative, the Sea of Helcar) that was destroyed
either with the sinking of Beleriand or the changing of the world.

name: Bay of Rómenna
text:
The BAY OF RÓMENNA was a bay situated just outside the city of Rómenna
in Númenor.


History

Within the bay closer to the coastline was the isle of Tol Uinen where
stood the tower of Calmindon. For hundreds of years, the mariners of the
great Númenórean navy left the island by way of this bay in their ships
to explore the world. In SA 3319, the nine ships of the remaining
Faithful left the doomed island for Middle-earth through this bay.

name: Dor Dínen
text:
DOR DÍNEN was a relinquished part of the East Beleriand, north of
Doriath.

Contained by one of the upper branches of the Esgalduin (bordering Nan
Dungortheb) and the Aros (bordering Himlad), it was said that no one had
lived there for ages. To the south lay Neldoreth, and Ered Gorgoroth to
the north. The region was best known for the Arossiach, which connected
the Esgalduin and Aros.


Etymology

_DOR DÍNEN_ was Sindarin for 'Silent land'
position: Between the rivers Esgalduin and Aros, north of Doriath and south of, Ered Gorgoroth
description: "Where nothing dwelt"

name: Tarn Aeluin
text:
TARN AELUIN also known as AELUIN was the name given by the grey-elves
and the Edain to a small clear lake in eastern Dorthonion in the centre
of the highlands, at the entrance of the shallow pass which led to
Ladros.

It is said to have been hallowed by Melian the Maia. It was here
that Barahir and his twelve comrades hid from Morgoth's forces after the
Dagor Bragollach.


Etymology

_TARN AELUIN_ was a Sindarin word that meant 'Blue-mere'.
description: A lake of clear waters with wild heaths about it

name: Caves of the Forgotten
text:
The CAVES OF THE FORGOTTEN was a place in Aman where Ar-Pharazôn and his
great army are imprisoned.


History

The caves were formed when Ilúvatar caused the hills of the Calacirya to
fall on the army of Ar-Pharazôn, after the king and his followers broke
the Ban of the Valar by invading Aman. It is here that they remain until
the end of the world when they are prophesized to arise during the Last
Battle, Dagor Dagorath or the Final Battle.

name: Forest Gate
text:
FOREST GATE was the western entrance to the northern part of the Forest
of Mirkwood beginning with the Elven-path.

It was described as an arch-like opening made by two large ivy layered,
lichen covered trees bearing only a few blackened leaves, that had leant
together forming a dark narrow tunnel.


History

In _the Hobbit_

Thorin and Company passed through the Forest Gate on the twenty-fifth of
July 2941 after Gandalf departed with the ponies.

name: House of the Hundred Chimneys
text:
The HOUSE OF THE HUNDRED CHIMNEYS was the house of Gilfanon in Tol
Eressëa in the earlier forms of the legendarium.


History

The House of the Hundred Chimneys was located near the Bridge of
Tavrobel in the land of Tavrobel on the island of Tol Eressëa. Nothing
else of its description is known, except that it was very old, possibly
dating back to the early days of Elven settlement of the island, and
that Gilfanon invited the Man Eriol to his house.

name: Dol Baran
text:
DOL BARAN was a hill in Rohan.

Dol Baran lay between Isengard and the Gap of Rohan, at the southernmost
foot of the Misty Mountains. It was covered with heather.


History

Dol Baran was the place where Rohirrim had made a camp at which Pippin
looked into the Palantír of Orthanc (a different location than in the
third film), and was also where a Nazgûl, atop a Fellbeast, was seen
flying. 


Etymology

_Dol Baran_ is Sindarin for 'Golden-brown hill'.

name: Ivy Bush
text:
The Ivy
Bush was a small inn on the Bywater Road, in the Westfarthing of the
Shire, where beer was served.

Many Hobbits from both Bywater and Hobbiton frequently came here to
drink and socialize with one another. One of its usual patrons was
Hamfast Gamgee, also known as “the Gaffer”. The Ivy Bush was where the
Gaffer explained Frodo Baggins' history and connection to Bilbo Baggins,
as well as described Bilbo's return to the Shire after his adventure.

name: Barad Nimras
text:
BARAD NIMRAS was a tower built by Finrod in FA 65, on the
Falas between the havens of Brithombar and Eglarest. It was built to
keep watch, should Morgoth try to assail them from the sea.


Etymology

_Barad nimras_ is Sindarin, for 'tower of the white horn'.

Earlier names

_TINDOBEL_ was the original name ascribed to this location. In revisions
of _The Silmarillion_ that name was replaced by _INGILDON_, which later
was finally emended, to _Barad Nimras._
description: White tower overlooking the sea

name: Lake Mithrim
text:
LAKE OF MITHRIM was a great lake in the land of Mithrim in Hithlum.


History

Lake Mithrim was where on the second year of the sun where the Ñoldor
first dwelt in Middle-earth: the Sons of Fëanor on the northern shore
and Fingolfin's host on the southern shore.

It was fed by three streams coming from the Ered Wethrin.


Etymology

The word _Mith_ means Grey and _rim_ means Folk so therefore it means
_Lake Grey-folk_ or perhaps _Lake of the Grey-folk_ in Sindarin.

name: Ringol
text:
_RINGOL_ was the name of a great tower upon which the mighty lamp Ormal
sat.

It was raised by the Valar to house the Southern of the Two Lamps,
Ormal. It was placed in the south of Middle-earth, and together with the
northern lamp Illuin lit up all of Arda.

Ringol was destroyed by Melkor, and collapsed. This ruined a great part
of Middle-earth, and waters most likely from the eastern ocean flowed in
to fill the void. Later here was formed the inland Sea of Ringol.

name: Firienfeld
text:
FIRIENFELD was a grassy field in Dunharrow between the Irensaga and
Starkhorn.

It served as an encampment and gathering point for the Men of Rohan
during times of war.

The road to the Dimholt ran through tents and pavilions that were raised
as shelter for the soldiers and their horses.


History

The Rohirrim were camped here in twenty-eight century of the Third Age
during their war with Dunlendings. It was also encamped by the Rohirrim
during the War of the Ring.

name: Losgar
text:
LOSGAR was a region located at the mouth of the Firth of Drengist in
Middle-earth.


History

Losgar was the place that Fëanor and his followers landed and where he
ordered the burning the Swanships that he stole from the Teleri of
Alqualondë. Fingolfin observed this from Araman in Aman and realized
that he had been betrayed thus forcing him and his followers to undergo
a long and hard trek across the Helcaraxë to Middle-earth.


Etymology

_LOSGAR_ is a Sindarin word.

name: Eldalondë
text:
ELDALONDË also known as ELDALONDË THE GREEN was a seaport on the
western coast of Númenor where the river Nunduinë emptied into the Bay
of Eldanna.

It was surrounded by the pleasant and fair region of Nísimaldar.


History

During the Second Age, Eldalondë was the primary seaport by which the
Elves would arrive from Tol Eressëa to the west to meet with the
Elf-friends (The Faithful) amongst the Numenoreans.


Etymology

Eldalondë is a Quenya word that meant “Elf-haven”.
position: Western Númenor, at the mouth of the Nunduinë
description: Most beautiful of all of Númenor's havens

name: Square of the Palace
text:
The SQUARE OF THE PALACE, also named the SQUARE OF THE KING, was a named
location in the center  of the city of Gondolin next to the Place of
the Well , and was one of the many places that bore the slaughter of
the Fall of Gondolin. This square was the grounds of the last strong
defense of Tuor's battalions (remnants of the many Houses of the
Gondolindrim whom he had gathered), during the latter half of the
battle.

The tower and palace of King Turgon were in this square.

name: Nindalf
text:
The NINDALF, or WETWANG was a swampland that was located to the south of
Emyn Muil and east of the Great River Anduin, fed by the great inland
delta of the Entwash. The Dead Marshes lie further east, and may be an
extension of Nindalf.


History

The Nindalf was a perilous and dangerous fen that stretched out over a
wide area for many miles. Celeborn explained this to the Fellowship as
they prepared to depart Lórien down the river Anduin.


Etymology

_NINDALF_ was a Sindarin word.
position: South of Emyn Muil, east of Anduin
description: A large trackless fen

name: Balin's Tomb
text:
BALIN'S TOMB was a mausoleum of white marble that was located deep
within Moria on the eastern side of the Misty Mountains to the north of
the great chamber of the Dwarrowdelf.

This room was also the Chamber of Mazarbul, or the Chamber of Records.
The tomb in the center of the room, on which the beam of light fell,
housing the body of Gimli's fallen cousin Balin. 

Upon the tomb, the words were inscribed in cirth runes (rendered in
Khuzdul) saying:

BALIN SON OF FUNDIN
LORD OF MORIA

name: Carchost
text:
CARCHOST is one of the two Towers of the Teeth built by the men of
Gondor for defence against the servants of the Dark Lord but later
abandoned by them and then occupied by their enemies. This tower, along
with Narchost, overlooks the Morannon, the Black Gate of Mordor, and is
situated on one side, some say the east (or north), of Cirith Gorgor,
the Haunted Pass, on a hill that is at the extreme western end of the
Ered Lithui.


Etymology

The name, Carchost, means “Fang Tower” in Sindarin.

name: Naith of Lórien
text:
The NAITH OF LÓRIEN or GORE was the heart of the Elven realm of Lórien,
where the Caras Galadhon was located.

The Naith was located in the angle between the rivers Silverlode and
Anduin.


History

The Naith was where the Fellowship first encountered the sentinels of
Lórien and through which they were led to the Lord and Lady in Caras
Galadhon, and where Frodo first experienced the feeling of having
entered a corner of the Elder Days.


Etymology

NAITH is a Sindarin word which means “angle”.

name: Grey Wood
text:
The GREY WOOD was a small wooded area between the Warning beacon of Amon
Dîn and Mount Mindolluin just outside the Stonewain Valley and the
Drúadan Forest.


History

During the War of the Ring, the Drúedain revealed the way through the
Stonewain Valley to King Théoden and the Rohirrim and they passed
through the Grey Wood and on to Minas Tirith. After the war, King
Aragorn II Elessar came to the Grey Wood and there granted
Ghân-buri-Ghân and his people the Drúadan Forest to dwell in
undisturbed.

name: Harad Road
text:
The '''Harad road '''was a road that was used by the armies of Harad to
come to Mordor.

It ran from the Black Gate through Northern Ithilien to the cross-roads
and then further south crossing the Poros river and the river of Harnen
and thus entering Haradwaith.


History

On this road, near Emyn Arner, Faramir and the rangers of Ithilien
ambushed the Harad army and met Frodo, Sam and Gollum in the ''Lord of
the Rings the Two Towers chapters _Of Herbs and Stewed Rabbit_ and _The
Window on the West_.

name: Framsburg
text:
FRAMSBURG was a small hamlet located on the northeastern edge of the
Misty Mountains, on the other side of the spur from Angmar. It was the
old capital of the Éothéod, founded by their brave Chieftain Fram, the
slayer of Scatha, in TA 2000. It was later abandoned in around TA 2509
when the Éothéod traveled south to their new homes in Calenardhon, which
then became known as Rohan.

The ruins of Framsburg apparently survived into the late Third Age and
early Fourth Age, and nothing further is known of it.
position: North-western Wilderland, at the source of the Anduin
description: Capital of the Éothéod

name: Walls of Night
text:
THE WALLS OF NIGHT are the extraordinary walls that surrounded Arda in
ancient times, beyond Ekkaia, the Encircling Sea.

In the west and east of the World, Ekkaia was wide, and the Walls were a
great distance from land. In the north and south, however, the
Encircling Sea was much narrower. This was how Melkor returned into the
World during the Years of the Lamps of the Valar, coming secretly over
the Walls of Night into the north of Arda, and building there his
fortress of Utumno beyond the knowledge of the Valar.
description: Walls surrounding Arda

name: Eglarest
text:
EGLAREST was one of the two (the other was Brithombar) great walled
havens at the mouth of the River Nenning.

It was founded by the Falathrim under Círdan during the Years of the
Trees and was haven of peace until it was besieged by the forces of
Morgoth during the First Battle of Beleriand. Relieved and fortified by
the elves of Nargothrond in FA 65, after the return of the Noldor,
Eglarest and its sister city endured until FA 473 when it was destroyed
by the forces of Morgoth.


See Also

-   Havens of the Falas
position: Falas, at the mouth of the Nenning

name: Forostar
text:
FOROSTAR was the northernmost province of Númenor.

It was a great north-pointing cape about 300 miles from base to tip,
rising from infertile stony plains to chilly, windswept high-lands and
ultimately towering sea-cliffs.


History

The only named settlement in the province was Ondosto located in its
south eastern quarter along the main road. The Tower on Sorontil built
by Tar-Meneldur to observe the stars on the peak of Sorontil near the
northern cape of the island, was also another noted feature of the
province.

name: Region
text:
REGION (pronounced Reh-gi-on) was the main forest of Doriath, which made
up the majority of this elven realm.

Region lay between the rivers Aros and Esgalduin, both of which were
completely surrounded by the Girdle of Melian. The capital city of
Menegroth stood near its northern bounds.

The forest consisted mainly of holly trees.


History

Eöl, the Dark Elf, once dwelt there in the early days, but was not
content and obtained permission from the king to dwell outside its
boundaries, in exchange for the sword Anglachel.

name: Rhosgobel
text:
RHOSGOBEL was the home of the wizard Radagast the Brown.


History

Rhosgobel was located somewhere on the southwest borders of Mirkwood.
The dates of when Radagast dwelt there are unclear, as is its exact
location within the wood. It is unclear if he was the only inhabitant of
Rhosgobel; the alternate view being that it was simply a Woodman
settlement where Radagast resided.


Etymology

The term ''RHOSGOBEL ''originates from the Sindarin words _rhosg_
(“brown”) and _gobel_ (“enclosed dwelling, walled house or village”).
position: Rhovanion, on the eaves of Mirkwood
description: Home of Radagast

name: Darkness of the North
text:
The DARKNESS OF THE NORTH or the NORTHERN DARK was an area in the
farthest northern parts of Arda during the Second Age.

The Darkness of the North was created after the destruction of the
Beleriand at the end of the First Age. It could be reached by sea by
traveling farthest north in both the Belegaer and the Inner Seas. The
Númenóreans sailed to this area as they did to the Nether Darkness in
the far south during their explorations of the world.

It was likely a cold place. Its existence after the Change of the World
is not known.

name: Bay of Balar
text:
The BAY OF BALAR was an ocean inlet of Belegaer located south of
Beleriand, fed by the river Sirion.

It was presumably created in the cataclysms that accompanied the
struggles of the Valar with Morgoth long before recorded history.

The Isle of Balar was a large island in the bay.


Etymology

The bay's name refers to the Valar (and Maiar), especially Ossë, who was
associated with continental shelf areas. In Telerin the name _Valar_ was
BALAI, and in Sindarin the form it took was eventually BALA.


See Also

-   Balar (disambiguation)
position: South of Arvernien, off of Belegaer
description: Large bay including the Isle of Balar

name: Mount Gram
text:
MOUNT GRAM was one of the peaks adjoining to the Misty Mountains by its
southern roots leading into the Ettenmoors.


History

The mountain was long inhabited by a group of Orcs led by their chief
(until the year 2747 of the Third Age), Golfimbul. They terrorized some
of the inhabitants of eastern Eriador which included the Shire.

In TA 2747, the growing troops of Orcs from Mount Gram attacked the
Shire and so caused the Battle of Greenfields. Those orcs fell in battle
against Bandobras Took and their leader Golfimbul was killed by
him.

name: Mouths of Sirion
text:
MOUTHS OF SIRION was the delta of the river Sirion where it flowed into
the Bay of Balar. It was located in the West Beleriand in the land of
Arvernien.

The Havens of Sirion located around this land , as well as a
marshland and a land of reeds called Arlisgion .


History

This area may have been inhabited at an earlier time by the Teleri but
when they departed for the Havens of the Falas the area was inhabited,
until Círdan established a refuge there. People, both elves and men
began arriving here as the forces of Morgoth began to gain ground.
position: North-east corner of the Bay of Balar
description: Marshy region with a forest of reeds
other_names: Havens of Sirion, Lisgardh, Havens of the Ships

name: Endless Stair
text:
The ENDLESS STAIR was a long stairway in Moria built by the Dwarves.


History

These stairs climbed from the lowest point in Middle-earth, to the very
peak of the Zirakzigil. At the top of the Endless Stair, a windy chamber
known as Durin's Tower was carved from the rock of the mountain, where
the Dwarf kings would gaze out over the Misty Mountains. After
abandoning Moria in the Third Age, the stair and chamber became legend
among the Dwarves. The top of it was destroyed during the battle between
Gandalf and the Balrog, on January 23-25 of 3019.

name: Bywater
text:
Bywater
was a village in the Shire, lying within the Westfarthing near Hobbiton,
and along Bywater Road. Bywater was located on The Water, a small stream
that ran through part of the Shire, and where the village takes its name
from. It was home to the famous Green Dragon Inn.


History

Bywater was the site of the Battle of Bywater on November 3, 3019. It
was in this battle that the War of the Ring ended, as it saw the defeat
and death of the rebel Istari Saruman at the hands of Gríma Wormtongue
(who was, in turn, shot by three unnamed Hobbit archers).
description: A small village by the Bywater Pool

name: Starkhorn
text:
The STARKHORN was a large jagged snow-clad peak that rises in the inner
regions of the White Mountains of Middle-earth.


History

Starkhorn can be seen quite clearly from the southern end of the refuge
of Dunharrow in Rohan. From its feet springs the Snowbourn River, whose
widening valley runs northwards through the mountains to emerge onto the
plains of Rohan. The Rohirrim called that valley Harrowdale, and built
their courts of Edoras at its mouth, from where the lonely white peak of
the Starkhorn could be seen along the straight length of the valley.
description: Large mountain, jagged snow-clad peak

name: Forlindon
text:
FORLINDON was the northern part of Lindon which is separated from
Harlindon, the southern part by the Gulf of Lune along the coasts of
western Middle-earth.

The Elven-haven and harbour of Forlond lay on the southern coast of the
region, and was ruled by Gil-galad.

Like the rest of Lindon it is a remnant of the Beleriand that sank under
the Great Sea after the War of Wrath, at the end of the First Age.


Etymology

The name _FORLINDON_ possibly means “North Lindon”, from the Quenya word
_formen_ and Sindarin words _for, forn, forod_ (“north”) and
Lindon.
position: North of Gulf of Lune, west of Blue Mountains

name: Court of the Fountain
text:
The COURT OF THE FOUNTAIN was the courtyard that was built upon the top
of the prow of Minas Tirith. The courtyard was where the house of power
in Gondor lies and where the White Tree of Gondor grows. It was guarded
by the Guards of the Citadel.




Layout

The court covers the flat area at the top of Minas Tirith's prow. It has
several small patches of grass growing on it, with a fountain in the
middle. One can walk out onto the prow from this court, and can access
the bench-like seat at the end of the prow. One can also access the
Citadel from the court.

name: Cabed-en-Aras
text:
CABED-EN-ARAS was a deep gorge near Brethil through which the river
Taeglin ran.


History

Cabed-en-Aras was known for being the place where Túrin slew Glaurung
when the dragon was trying to get through the ravine to attack Brethil.
Later both were found by Nienor and as a result of Glaurung's
machinations she cast herself down the ravine, which was then named by
Túrin the _Cabed Naeramarth,_ the Leap of Dreadful Doom. The spot was
later considered haunted, and even animals did not come there.


Etymology

Cabed-en-Aras was Sindarin for _Leap of the Deer_.
description: Deep gorge, with Teiglin flowing below

name: Cirith Thoronath
text:
CIRITH THORONATH was a pass in the Echoriath northwest of Gondolin.


History

Cirith Thoronath was the place through which the refugees from the Fall
of Gondolin made their escape after passing through Idril's Secret Way.
It was here that they were set upon by a Balrog, who was challenged by
Glorfindel, leading to a fierce battle between the two. After ruining
its helmet and piercing its belly, Glorfindel was dragged by the demon
over a nearby cliff, with both falling to their deaths. 


Etymology

_Cirith Thoronath_ was Sindarin for 'cleft of the eagles'.

name: Upbourn
text:
UPBOURN was a hamlet located in Rohan, south of Edoras on the banks of
the Snowbourn in the valley of Harrowdale.

Upbourn was one of the small villages that lay in the White Mountains,
in the valley of the River Snowbourn known as Harrowdale. This placed it
close to Rohan's capital of Edoras, and indeed it was on the road
between Edoras and the mountain refuge of Dunharrow. Thus Théoden and
his armies of Rohirrim passed through Upbourn during the War of the
Ring, at the beginning of the journey that would lead them east to the
Battle of the Pelennor Fields.

name: Almaren
text:
ALMAREN (Quenya; IPA: ; meaning _blessed place_), also known as the ISLE
OF ALMAREN, was an island located in the Great Lake. It was the first
home of the Valar, in the middle of Arda.


Description

Not much is known about the actual landscape of the island; only that it
was covered with green grass.


History

Almaren was raised sometime after the retreat of Melkor when the earth
had become firm and flat. It was at this place where the light of the
Two Lamps mingled. Almaren was attacked and damaged by Melkor, and the
Valar moved far to the West, to Valinor.
description: Large green island, fairest land during the Years of the Lamps
position: In the centre of the Great Lake in early Middle-earth
events: Spring of Arda, Wedding of Tulkas and Nessa

name: Rómenna
text:
RÓMENNA was the main seaport of Númenor on its east coast.


History

Rómenna was a great seaport and many of the realms greatest shipyards
were located here. The great Númenórean mariner Vëantur had a house here
and his friend Aldarion came there often and kept his ships there as
well. Here much of the traffic with the old lands of Middle-earth
passed. When Ar-Gimilzôr came to power, the Faithful of Númenor were
relocated to Rómenna late in Númenor's history so that the King's Men
could watch them.


Etymology

Rómenna is a Quenyan word that means 'Eastwards'.
position: Eastern coast of the province of Arandor.
description: Chief seaport of Númenor and shipyard

name: Mount Taras
text:
MOUNT TARAS was a mountain in the Ered Wethrin (Mountains of Shadow) in
western Nevrast near the coast of the western Beleriand.

Mount Taras was tall and dark and reached high into the sky and was
topped with clouds and stood high above a green cape that jutted out
into the sea.


History

The city of Vinyamar was built under it. Tuor visited here during his
travels in Nevrast and was near where he spoke with Ulmo. The
mountain was either destroyed during the War of Wrath or simply sunk
under the sea as the rest of the Beleriand did at the end of the First
Age.
description: Tall, dark, cloud-capped mountain
position: Westernmost peak between Nevrast and West Beleriand

name: Hobbiton Hill
text:
HOBBITON HILL, also called the THE HILL, was a hill in the Westfarthing
between Hobbiton and Overhill. It was on this hill that Bag End stood as
well as Bagshot Row and its residents, the Party Field, and the Party
Tree. The hill had many other large trees as well.


History

During the Shire's rule by Lotho and Saruman much of the hill's places
and trees were dug up and destroyed, and a large sand and gravel quarry
stood in the place of Bagshot Row. During the Scouring of the Shire, the
Party Tree was replaced by a Mallorn, and Bagshot Row was replaced by
New Row.

name: Lake Evendim
text:
LAKE EVENDIM, or “NENUIAL”, was one of the many lakes of Middle-earth.

The elven name _Nenuial_ is Sindarin for “Lake of Twilight”, suggesting
that the lake was best seen at that time of day. The lake was about 100
miles north of the Shire in northern Eriador. It was approximately 50
miles from north to south and 20 miles east to west. It was bounded on
the west by the Emyn Uial (Hills of Evendim) and on the south by a ridge
of hills not named. On its southern shore was Annúminas, the first
capital of Arnor.

The Baranduin flowed out of this lake towards the east.
position: Central Eriador, in the Hills of Evendim west of Fornost Erain
description: Large lake partly encircled by hills

name: Brandy Hall
text:
BRANDY HALL was a house built by Gorhendad Oldbuck in Buckland, who
changed his name to “Brandybuck”. It covered a low hill in Buckland and
was expanded as the Brandybuck family grew. By the time of the War of
the Ring, the hall had “three large front-doors, many side-doors, and
about a hundred windows.” The Gaffer referred to it as “a regular
warren.” It was Frodo's childhood home before he was taken in by his
uncle Bilbo Baggins.

The head of that family was called the Master of the Hall, and his
authority was acknowledged between the villages of Stock and Rushey.
description: Ancestral home of the Brandybuck Family

name: Dome of Stars
text:
The DOME OF STARS was a great beautiful dome built by Elendil in the
city of Osgiliath, on top of a bridge that crossed the river Anduin.

Within this building was kept Osgiliath's Palantír. It was destroyed
when Castamir the Usurper ordered his men to burn the city of Osgiliath
during the Kin-strife in Gondor, and the Palantír was lost in the
Anduin. This Palantír kept communication with the Ithil stone, Anor
stone, and the stones in the North and Isengard. Its use was halted when
the Nazgul took Minas Ithil and turned it into Minas Morgul, The Tower
of Black Sorcery.

name: Tower of Tar-Minastir
text:
The TOWER OF TAR-MINASTIR was a high tower in the western part of
Númenor.

It was located in the province of Andustar south of the coastal city of
Andúnië and could be reached by a road that connected Ondosto to
Andúnië.


History

The Tower was built by Tar-Minastir, the eleventh King of Númenor
sometime between SA 1731 and SA 1869 to gaze upon the West. Tar-Palantir
spent much time here ever yearning for the West and watching for any
ship embarking from Tol Eressëa, but none ever did ever again. The tower
along with everything else perished in the Downfall of Númenor.

name: Lithlad
text:
LITHLAD was a great plain in Mordor, southeast of the plateau Gorgoroth.
Long ages of continuous fallout from Mount Doom and possibly far older
volcanoes enriched the area with great amounts of ash, which enhanced
the ground making it ideal for dry-land farming.


History

It is known that Numenoreans once had dominion over Lithlad during the
Second Age, populated as a far off part of their empire. Being one of
many remote locations they visited, many lost artifacts and ancient
ruins remained there from their time.


Etymology

_Lithlad_ is a Sindarin word for 'ash-plain'.
position: Eastern Mordor, below the Ered Lithui and east of Gorgoroth
description: Barren dry plain

name: Tookland
text:
TOOKLAND was a
small section of The Shire west of Hobbiton between Waymeet, Whitwell,
and Tookbank in around Green-hill country.


History

Tookland was the land of the Tooks and many of the Took clan lived
there. During the Battle of Bywater, about 100 Tooks under Peregrin Took
(Pippin) marched to Bywater to assist in the Scouring of the Shire.
Before they left, the Tooks shot a few Ruffian scouts with arrows. These
ruffians had been keeping a watch on Tookland. The Tooks played a huge
role in The Battle of Bywater when they shot many Ruffians, as they were
skilled archers.

name: Tol Brandir
text:
TOL BRANDIR or Tindrock was an unclimbable island - unclimable because
of the sheer rock face which rose from the water at the base of the
mountain - with a huge pinnacle in the centre of the long lake called
Nen Hithoel. Trees grew on an area of the island, before above it was
more inaccessible rock; the mountain itself was capped at by a great
stone spire. It stood between the hills of Amon Hen and Amon Lhaw and
looked over the Falls of Rauros.

It is stated that no-one, man nor elf nor dwarf had ever set foot upon
this island.

de:Tol Brandir pl:Tol Brandir ru:Тол Брандир

name: Mittalmar
text:
The MITTALMAR was the central province of Númenor, containing Arandor
(or 'Kings'-land'), which itself was the most populous part of the
realm.

The land was Númenor's main pastoral land and consisted mainly of
grasslands and like most of Númenor it had a humid climate with mild
winters. It was oval in shape and ran about two-hundred miles from east
to west and over one-hundred and fifty miles from north to south. In its
near center was the mountain of Meneltarma, the Pillar of Heaven. Its
two main rivers Nunduinë and Siril (Númenor's only ones) were present
mostly in this region.

name: Himling
text:
HIMLING was a small island about twenty-five miles off
the coast of northern Lindon in the northern part of the Belegaer, and
about a dozen miles east of the island of Tol Fuin according to _The
Atlas of Middle-earth_.

No one is known to have lived there either in the Second or Third ages
or beyond.


History

During the First Age of Middle-earth, Himling was once a hill known as
Himring which was the location of the realm of Maedhros, the eldest son
of Fëanor. After the sinking of the Beleriand at the end of the War of
Wrath, the peak of the hill remained above water as an island.
description: Tall flat-topped treeless hill, fortified
position: Between the Pass of Aglon and Maglor's Gap; later as an island in, Belegaer

name: Ash Mountains
text:
The ASH MOUNTAINS, or ERED LITHUI was a mountain range that formed the
northern border of Mordor.


Description

According to the _The Atlas of Middle-earth_, the range was some 500
miles in length stretching from the Black Gate and Cirith Gorgor, where
it met the Ephel Dúath in the west and Rhûn in the far east. Barad-dûr
stood on an outcrop of this range on the plateau of Gorgoroth to its
south. These mountains were probably heavily blackened by the
volcanic activity of Mount Doom hence the name.


Etymology

The Sindarin name Ered Lithui meant 'Ash Mountains' or 'Ashy
Mountains'.
description: Known for being the northern border mountain range were behind lies the, dreaded land of Gorgoroth.
events: Wainriders sudden assault upon King Ondoher

name: The Yale
text:
THE YALE was the name of the low-lying lands of the Shire's Eastfarthing
that lay along the northern side of the long road from Stock westwards
to Tuckborough.

This seems to have been a sparsely populated area, and in fact the map
of the Shire in _The Lord of the Rings_ marks only a single building
here.


Etymology

The meaning of the Yale's name is obscure. The well-known English
personal and placename “Yale” has its origins in a Welsh expression
meaning “fertile upland.” Its use may suggest that the Hobbits who named
it had contacts with “strange” languages, possibly those of Dunland.

name: Lake Helevorn
text:
LAKE HELEVORN was a deep, dark lake in Thargelion just south of Mount
Rerir in the northeastern Beleriand.

According to _The Atlas of Middle-earth_, it appeared to span around
twenty miles from its west to east shoreline.


History

After the Return of the Ñoldor, Caranthir, the fourth son of Fëanor took
up residence along Lake Helevorn's shorelines. During the Dagor
Bragollach, Glaurung the dragon polluted and defiled its waters. The
lake as well as Caranthir's domain was destroyed at the conclusion of
the War of Wrath.


Etymology

_HELEVORN_ is a Sindarin word that meant 'Black-Glass'.

name: Udûn (Mordor)
text:
UDÛN was a depressed valley located in northwestern Mordor. It laid
between Cirith Gorgor and the Isenmouthe, and was traversed by large
armies of Sauron in times of war.

Within its circumference were many Orc-holds (as told in _The Return of
the King_), including Durthang, the forges, and the forts at Carach
Angren.


History

Udûn originated with the creation of the lands of Mordor. During both
the war of the Last Alliance and the War of the Ring, the vast armies of
Mordor passed through here and out the Black Gate to confront their
enemies.


Etymology

_UDÛN_ meant “hell” in Sindarin.

name: Mountains of Mirkwood
text:
The MOUNTAINS OF MIRKWOOD, also known as
EMYN-NU-FUIN, is a group of smaller Mountains located in the north end
of Mirkwood.

They were located just west of the Elvenking's halls in Mirkwood.


History

During the days when Mirkwood was known as Greenwood the Great, the
mountains were known as EMYN DUIR or the DARK MOUNTAINS, and were
probably inhabited by Silvan Elves. The Giant Spiders of Mirkwood, and
goblins have made their home here. The goblins were mainly newcomers to
the mountains, fleeing into them after the Battle of Five Armies, where
they built dwellings amongst the steep slopes.
position: Northern Mirkwood, south of the Woodland Realm

name: Old Guesthouse
text:
The OLD GUESTHOUSE was the main inn in the city of Minas Tirith located
on Rath Celerdain, directly behind the Othram near the Great Gates.


History

The Old Guesthouse was a large building made of grey stone that had
become weathered with age. It consisted of two wings with a narrow
greensward that stood between them and small house with many windows and
pillared porch with a flight of steps leading down to a grass yard. Many
Gondorian soldiers were to be found here.

Pippin visited here after Beregond went on guard duty.

The Old Guesthouse may have been damaged during the Siege of
Gondor.

name: Ered Lómin
text:
The ERED LÓMIN were a range of mountains that formed the northwestern
edge of Hithlum in Beleriand.

Ered Lómin is bordered on its east and southeastern side by the lands of
Lammoth and Losgar. Hidden in this mountain range is Cirith Ninniach,
and it is guarded by the Gate of the Ñoldor which is further up the
cliff. The mountain range joins the Ered Wethrin in southern
Dor-lómin.


History

The route by which Fëanor and the rest of the Ñoldor took when they
returned to Middle-earth and entered Hithlum was through these
mountains. 


Etymology

_Ered Lómin_ is Sindarin for 'Echoing Mountains'.
events: Landing of Fëanor's host at the Firth of Drengist

name: Dimholt
text:
The DIMHOLT was a forest situated at the base of the Dwimorberg
mountain, past Dunharrow.

The Dimholt was a forest of pine wood and fir. An ancient road is
visibly forged there, that leads to a glen where a standing stone that
lies in front of the Dark Door, which signifies the entrance to the
Paths of the Dead.

The pathways lead under the Dwimorberg mountain and have been haunted by
the spirits of the men of the mountain of the Third Age. Even Legolas, a
woodland Elf, could not long endure being under those trees.


Etymology

_DIMHOLT_ was a Sindarin word that literally translating to 'dark wood'

name: Mountains of Moria
text:
The MOUNTAINS OF MORIA are the three great mountains peaks of --
Celebdil, Caradhras and Fanuidhol -- in the Misty Mountains of
Middle-earth.


History

They are all within a few dozen miles of each other and formed part of
the Misty Mountains, beneath which Khazad-dûm was delved by the Dwarves.
The main body of their city, which was later called _Moria_, seems to
have been beneath Celebdil, which they called Zirakzigil, and which was
crowned by Durin's Tower.

During the Quest of the Ring, the Fellowship attempted to transverse the
mountain's tallest; most perilous, and most unforgiving peak: Caradhras.

name: Ettendales
text:
The ETTENDALES was a cold, frozen land north of Rivendell, adjacent to
the Ettenmoors and the Coldfells,


History

The Ettendales was a dangerous land inhabited by Trolls and Giants.
These were cold lands far to the north of Rivendell and little known to
any but the Trolls that inhabited them. Aragorn's grandfather Arador had
ventured into these hills and dales but he was captured and killed by
the Snow-trolls that lurked there.


Etymology

_ETTENDALES_ are literally 'giant-valleys'. It's unclear whether the
location in fact is a home to giants.

'etten'- comes from Old English _eoten_, meaning _Giant_.

name: Dáin's Halls
text:
DÁIN'S HALLS was a name used for the halls that formed the capital of
the Grey Mountains, the name coming from the Dwarf-king Dáin I.


History

The Halls of Dáin were probably originally founded by the first exiled
dwarves from Khazad-dûm who had fled the city because of the Balrog.
However because there is no information on the halls, it can only be
assumed that it was the capital of Durin's folk at the time.

In TA 2589 , Dáin was killed by a great Cold-drake along with his son
Frór at the entrance to the city. A year later, most of Durin's Folk
abandoned the mountains, and left for Erebor and the Iron Hills.
description: Seat of the King of Durin's Folk
cultures: Dwarves of the Grey Mountains, Durin's Folk

name: Amon Lanc
text:
AMON LANC, the Naked Hill, was a hill in the southern parts of Greenwood
the Great. It had once been the capital of the Woodland Realm of the
Silvan Elves under Oropher in the Second Age.

Around a millennium after his defeat, Sauron came to Amon Lanc and
reoccupied Oropher's abandoned stronghold. The hill and fortress were
then together called Dol Guldur, and the wood in which it stood became
known as Mirkwood.

In the Fourth Age, southern Mirkwood became known as East Lórien and
Amon Lanc obviously became part of it.


Etymology

_Amon Lanc_ is a Sindarin name, consisting of _amon_ (“hill”) + _lanc_
(“naked”).

name: Sammath Naur
text:
The SAMMATH NAUR was a structure and hall upon and within Mount Doom, at
which Frodo met his final struggle against the One Ring.


History

Sammath Naur was located in the Cracks of Doom. Sauron forged the One
Ring in the mid-Second Age there, and this was the only location in
which the One Ring could be destroyed. Therefore, it was the destination
for Frodo Baggins and the Quest of the Ring.

The final fated drama that put an end to the One Ring and to Gollum was
played out in this chamber of doom, after which it was destroyed, along
with the mountain.


Etymology

_Sammath Naur_ is Sindarin for 'Chambers of Fire'.

name: Bamfurlong
text:
BAMFURLONG, the name for MAGGOT'S FARM, was the farmland of Farmer
Maggot located in the Marish, in the Eastfarthing of the Shire.


History

Bamfurlong was boggy in nature and made for above ground habitation
rather than the traditional Hobbit-hole. It also made excellent ground
for growing mushrooms. Bamfurlong included a huge turnip field and a
lane that led to a large, thatched house and outbuildings. The house and
buildings were built of brick and were protected by a high wall with a
wooden gate.


Etymology

Tolkien himself suggested the name Bamfurlong comes from Old English
meaning something akin to 'bean-field'.

name: Timeless Halls
text:
The TIMELESS HALLS were the place where Eru lived.

In Tolkien's depiction of them, they are similar to the concept of a
'Heaven' in that they exist outside the boundaries of the created world
and in that they do not have a physical form. It is unknown whether or
not they are to be the final destination of the souls of Men. This is a
distinct possibility, however. Created by Eru the one


History

The Music of the Ainur was composed here, as described in the
_Ainulindalë__,_ before the creation of the world. The Halls were also
the home of the Ainur that chose not to descend into Eä, and instead
chose to remain with Eru.

name: Kalórmë
text:
KALÓRMË was a mountain in the middle of the Wall of the Sun on the
continent of the Land of the Sun in the farthest east of Arda.


History

Kalórmë seems to be the second tallest mountain in the world of Arda
next to Taniquetil. It seems to have existed from the time after the
destruction of the Two Lamps but does not appear on maps after the
Change of the World as the Land of the Sun does not. When seen from
afar looking at it from the Farthest West, it appeared dim. Oromë
observed the peak at some point during the Hiding of Valinor.
The Girdle of Arda runs across this peak.


Etymology

Kalórmë meant 'Sun-rising-hill'.

name: Brown Lands
text:
The BROWN LANDS were a devastated region of Rhovanion. They were
bordered by the Emyn Muil in the South, Mirkwood in the north, and
Anduin in the east.


History

Historically, the lands were fertile plains where the Entwives had their
gardens. The lands were ruined by Sauron as a defense against the
advance of the Allies, and the Entwives were driven away.

When the Fellowship travels by boat down the Anduin, they see nothing
but barren, withered slopes without even scrub or grass. Even Aragorn
could not say what had caused such desolation. The only living thing
they see are black swans - spies of Sauron - flying overhead.
description: Barren, generally lifeless area east of the Anduin

name: Great Lake
text:
The GREAT LAKE was a large lake located in Arda during the time of the
Two Lamps in the Spring of Arda.

It was located in the middle of Arda in Middle-earth between the two
great lamp towers Helcar and Ringol. Amid it lay the Isle of Almaren,
where the Valar dwelt.


History

The Valar created the Great Lake and the Isle of Almaren after Melkor
was driven from Arda by Tulkas during the First War. Both were destroyed
along with the Two Lamps when Melkor returned from the outer darkness to
bring ruin to the Valar's works and as a result of this, the Great Lake
was scuttled and destroyed after Melkor threw down the Two Lamps.

name: Stonewain Valley
text:
STONEWAIN VALLEY was a valley of Gondor in the Third Age. It was in the
east of White Mountains, located deep within the Druadan forest.


History

King Théoden led the army of Rohan through this vale to aid Gondor. The
road that went through the valley was four horses wide, and had been
made in ancient days by the Men of Gondor as a route from the quarries
beneath Min-Rimmon to Minas Anor. By the time of the War of the Ring, it
was forgotten by Men. However, on March 13, 3019, King Théoden met
with Ghân-buri-Ghân, headman of the Woses, in the Druadan forest near
Dunharrow, and the latter revealed the existence of the old road.
position: Eastern White Mountains, Between Gondor and Rohan

name: Amon Ethir
text:
AMON ETHIR, also known as SPYHILL, was an artificial hill in the plain
of Talath Dirnen above the river Narog. Situated around a league (five
kilometres) east of the Doors of Nargothrond, its clear summit was used
by Finrod Felagund's spies to watch the surrounding lands.

The hill remaining standing after the Sack of Nargothrond and in these
later years Nienor encountered Glaurung the Dragon here, who had
blanketed the land with dragon-reek, with only the hill top above the
mists. Here he cast Nienor into a deep spell of forgetfulness.


Etymology

Amon Ethir meant 'Hill of spies' in Sindarin.

de:Amon Ethir pl:Amon Ethir ru:Амон Этир

name: Amon Gwareth
text:
AMON GWARETH was a stone hill that sat in the middle of the fair vale of
Tumladen in the First Age Elven city of Gondolin.


History

Amon Gwareth was a smooth, hard, and black hill of stone sitting in the
middle of the fair vale. It was on this hill of stone that the great and
beautiful city of Gondolin was built, and the hill acted as its
foundation. Amon Gwareth was located in the center of the fair vale of
Tumladen, which was located inside the Echoriath.

The great cliff of Caragdûr where Eöl was cast off of was located on its
north side near the North Gate.


Etymology

Amon Gwareth was a Sindarin word that meant 'Hill of Watch'.

name: Aldburg
text:
ALDBURG (OE. 'Old Fortress') was one of the oldest settlements of
Middle-earth, in Rohan. It was recorded to have been built by Eorl in
the region known as the Folde, some miles to the southeast of Edoras.
Though he and his family moved to Edoras early in Rohan's history,
Aldburg remained a seat of noblemen.

At the time of the War of the Ring, it was the home of King Théoden's
nephew Éomer, who was Third Marshal of the Mark, and heir of the
Kingship of Rohan himself.

In the _Lord of the Rings_ book-series, Aldburg is never referenced to,
and doesn't appear on the maps.

de:Aldburg es:Aldburg it:Aldburg nl:Aldburg pl:Aldburg ru:Альдбург
description: Seat of the Eorl the Young, later, Seat of the Third Marshal of the Mark
governance: Eorl the Young, later, the Third Marshal of the Mark

name: Nísimaldar
text:
NÍSIMALDAR was a wooded area surrounding the Númenórean coastal city of
Eldalondë in the western part of the island.


History

Nísimaldar was noted for its beautiful evergreen and fragrant trees that
grew there which the Elves of Tol Eressëa brought out of the West _(See:
Plants of Númenor)_. It was also the only place that the golden tree
_malinornë_ as well as others of the Mallorn strain.

The place was a great treasure to both Men and Elves who took great
delight in the many sweet smells that filled the air there.


Etymology

The name NÍSIMALDAR means “Fragrant trees”, from the Quenya terms
_nísima_ (“fragrant”) and _alda_ (“tree”).

name: Alalminórë
text:
ALALMINÓRË or LAND OF ELMS was a region in Tol Eressëa in the earlier
forms of the legendarium.


History

Alalminórë was a wooded area of Elm trees situated in the center of the
island. Many towns and villages were here ringed around the city of
Kortirion or Koromas, the island's principal city located in the center
of the region. It was also, where the Cottage of Lost Play was located
near Kortirion. It was known for being the fairest place on the island.

It was mentioned several times in the poem _Kortirion among the
Trees_.


Other Names

It was also known by its Gnomish (i.e. Sindarin) or Ñoldorin name _GAR
LOSSION_ (Place of Flowers).

name: Kortirion
text:
KÔRTIRION was the principal city of Tol Eressëa.

The city was located on a great hill at the very center of the island in
the region of Alalminórë, the 'Land of Elms'. The Cottage of Lost Play
was located somewhere outside of the city.


Etymology

The name meant approximately 'Great Watch-tower hill', 'Watch-tower
hill', or 'mighty tower / city on a hill'. 


Notes

KÔRTIRION was not described or mentioned in _The Silmarillion_. It was
only documented in _The Book of Lost Tales_, Part one and mapped out by
Karen Wynn Fonstad in her atlas of Middle-earth. It was also mentioned
in both the poem and song: _Kortirion among the Trees_ and _Kôr_.
description: Teleri (Falmari) of Aman possibly with help from the Ñoldor. Largest, city in Tol Eressëa

name: Long Lake
text:
The LONG LAKE was an oval-shaped lake situated at the confluence of the
Forest River and the northern reaches of the River Running, south of the
Lonely Mountain.

The lake was about twenty miles from north to south, and about five
miles from east to west at its widest.


History



The town of Laketown, referring to this lake, was (twice) built entirely
upon the lake itself, which thus formed a natural moat. After Smaug's
demise, his dying body fell into the lake with a mighty crash.
Smaug's remains could be seen sticking out of the water from the
shore of the lake, but people feared them and treasure-hunters did not
dare approach the carcass.

name: Derndingle
text:
Derndingle was a small bowl or depression in the forest of Fangorn in
which the Ents held meetings. These meetings were known as Entmoots.


History

This was the place in which the deliberations took place over whether to
go to war against Saruman in consequence of the depredations of his
Orcs. The Hobbits, Merry and Pippin, had been taken there by Treebeard
and stayed nearby with Quickbeam during the three days of the meeting.
The edge of the depression was lined with evergreens, but the bowl was
empty except for a few birches that grew in the bottom. The name,
'derndingle', means 'hidden hollow' in an ancient language of Men in
Middle-earth.

name: East Lórien
text:
EAST LÓRIEN was the name of the realm east of Lórien founded by Celeborn
after the War of the Ring.


Description

East Lórien comprised of southern Mirkwood including Dol Guldur with the
land of the Beornings and the Woodmen on its northern border, and the
lands of the Reunited Kingdom to its south.


History

After the cleansing and purification of Dol Guldur by Galadriel,
Celeborn claimed a large area east of Lórien and ruled there until he
grew weary of Lothlórien's diminished glory after the passing of his
wife and Nenya. After the departure of Celeborn, many people from Lórien
moved into it leaving Lórien with few of its former inhabitants.

name: Lanthir Lamath
text:
LANTHIR LAMATH was a sparkling and beautiful waterfall in Ossiriand at
the foot of the southern range of the Blue Mountains. It was part of a
stream of the river Adurant.

It was probably ruined after the destruction of Beleriand after the War
of Wrath.


History

Lanthir Lamath was well known for being near the house of Dior Eluchíl,
son of Beren and Lúthien, when he lived there before becoming the King
of Doriath. As the water cascaded downward, the light would reflect and
shimmer; this inspired the name of his daughter Elwing whose name means
“Star-spray”.


Etymology

_Lanthir Lamath_ is a Sindarin word that meant 'Waterfall of Echoing
Voices'.

name: Brithombar
text:
BRITHOMBAR was the name for the northern Haven of the Falas (the
southern was Eglarest) at the mouth of the River Brithon in the western
Beleriand.


History

Brithombar was founded by the Falathrim under Círdan during the Years of
the Trees and was haven of peace until it was besieged by the forces of
Morgoth during the First Battle of Beleriand. Relieved after the return
of the Noldor, the city was rebuild and strengthened by Finrod in FA 65.
Unfortunately, with Morgoth gaining the upper hand in the war it was
destroyed along with Eglarest in FA 473 after the Nirnaeth
Arnoediad<


Etymology

_BRITHOMBAR_ was a Sindarin word for 'Brithon-dwelling'.
position: Falas, at the mouth of the river Brithon

name: Túna
text:
TÚNA was a high green hill in the land of Aman.


History

Túna was located within a gap of the Pelóri (Mountains of Aman) so as to
allow the Eldar to be able to see the stars they so longed to see again
(as the stars were the first things that had ever beheld, and were
precious to them). The light of the Two Trees fell upon it from the west
side, and from the east it looked upon the yet sunless and moonless
Arda. Upon the top of Túna was built the great city of Tirion.

Towards the end of the Second Age in SA 3319, Ar-Pharazôn and his Great
Armament reached Túna and he and his soldiers camped there before they
were buried under mounds of earth by Eru.
description: High green hill topped by the city ofTirion
events: Arrival of Eärendil, destruction of Ar-Pharazôn

name: Crissaegrim
text:
The Crissaegrim were home to the great Eagles of Thorondor. The great
Eagles moved to The Crissaegrim after Morgoth's return to Thangorodrim.
It was here that Thorondor, the Lord of the Eagles lived, and from here
he watched for spies attempting to find the hidden city of Turgon in the
vale of the River Sirion.

The Crissaegrim formed a part of the southern Echoriath, which were the
_Encircling Mountains_ of Gondolin.


Etymology

_Crissaegrim_ is Sindarin for “cleft mountain peaks”, but in Tolkien's
stories the place is usually referred to as CIRITH THORONATH, the
“Eagles' Cleft”, or “Abode of Eagles” because the peaks were
inaccessible from the ground.
position: Southern part of Echoriad, south of Gondolin and north of Dimbar
events: The flight of Húrin and Huor into Gondolin
description: Unclimbable peaks protecting Gondolin from the south

name: Bay of Belfalas
text:
The BAY OF BELFALAS was a large southern bay in the Great Sea.

The Bay of Belfalas was the remainder of the eastern edge of the Great
Gulf that had divided Beleriand from the Lands to the South in the First
Age. After the end of the War of Wrath a large section of western
Middle-earth was drowned, and with the new coastline the Bay of Belfalas
extended from Andrast to the Mouths of Anduin, and then south past Umbar
to the unknown southern shores.

Most of the Rivers of Gondor flowed into the Bay of Belfalas, and it had
many smaller bays and capes.

The Bay was named for the region of Belfalas (or “Great Shore”), and in
it lay the rocky island of Tolfalas.
description: The Bay of Belfalas was the only part of the Great Gulf of Beleriand, that survived the War of Wrath.

name: Archet
text:
ARCHET is a remote settlement of Bree Land, it is a village set among
the trees on the edge of the Chetwood, east of Bree itself.


History

As Aragorn and the Hobbits left Bree on their way to Rivendell, they
started out in the direction of Archet to fool the crowd of
Bree-landers, although they turned aside into the Chetwood before
reaching the village itself. Later on in the War of the Ring, Archet's
woods became home to Ruffians. During the winter they attempted to
invade Bree itself, but were fought back. Their accomplices among the
Bree-men, Harry Goatleaf and Bill Ferny, escaped with them, and
apparently joined them in their forest camps near Archet.

name: Enchanted Isles
text:
The ENCHANTED ISLES were a chain of islands surrounding part of
Aman east of Valinor and all of Tol Eressëa set in the Shadowy Seas.


History

After the poisoning of the Two Trees and the Revolt of the Noldor, the
Valar created a series of islands to aid in the Hiding of Valinor. It
was said that anyone who set foot upon these isles would fall into a
great sleep until the Change of the World, with the exception of
Eärendil and Elwing who escaped enchantment by the light of the Silmaril
and the permission of the Valar. At the end of the Second Age, the
Enchanted Isles presumably went with Aman and Tol Eressëa after they
were removed from the circles of the world.

name: Ford of Bruinen
text:
The FORD OF BRUINEN was a way of crossing the river Bruinen (Loudwater),
located in Eriador.

At the beginning of the War of the Ring, Frodo Baggins raced on
Glorfindel's horse, towards the Ford of Bruinen, with the Ringwraiths in
hot pursuit behind them. At the Ford Frodo, poisoned by a deadly wound,
made his stand, and defied the Witch-king of Angmar. This lured the
Ringwraiths into the Bruinen - Elrond and Gandalf the Grey both released
a great flood from far away, which took the form of horses made out of
water due to Gandalf's magic. This flood killed the horses of the
Ringwraiths and their physical forms, which was the cause of their later
use of Fellbeasts.
position: Where the East-West Road crosses Bruinen, south-east of the Trollshaws., Near Rivendell
description: A shallow crossing with steep banks

name: Stock Road
text:
STOCK ROAD was a road in the Shire.

According to the _The Atlas of Middle-earth_, it ran through northern
Green-hill country from Tuckborough in the Westfarthing, through the
northern tip of the Southfarthing, and to the settlement of Woodhall and
eventually to Stock. According to the _The Complete Guide to
Middle-earth_, the road turned off from the Great East Road through
Green-hill country and the Woody End and ultimately to Stock.


History

On September 22, 3021, Frodo and Sam met Gildor Inglorion, the Keepers
of the Three Rings, and other Elves on Stock Road riding west to the
Grey Havens where they would leave Middle-earth for the Undying Lands
never to return.

name: Eastfold
text:
